label: Reacts strongly when separated from mother  needs to be close to him/her, especially in new places.

values.label: First Steps.take first steps without support (between months 12 and 15, some children take a bit longer).
Able to walk a few steps on toes while cruising using furniture as support.
While standing is able to rotate chest 90 degrees.
Can go from standing up to a sitting position without difficulty.
Even if able to walk, might prefer crawling as a more efficient way of locomotion for a while.
Able to crawl with one hand raised or while carrying an object.
Can firmly hold a crayon in his/her hand .
An improved pincer grasp allows better manipulation of thin objects like rings or strings  allows the baby to place small objects in bottles.
Object Grouping. might be able to group some items by shape (e.g., circle, square and triangle) and by primary  colors.
Imitation skills continue to improve replicates behaviors such as rubbing body with soap and feeding others.
Understands simple orders.
Says First Word With Intention.first recognizable words  might also point or look at the person or object while saying its name.
Can say about three words and understands many more.
Attempts to imitate lyrics or musical sounds of favourite songs.
Starts attempting to do more things alone, often realizing caregiver support is still required.
Solo Playing Begins. able to remain alone for longer periods of time  for  example, after waking up the baby  might play a few minutes before calling a parent.
Using limited words and improved  body language, the baby can better communicate desires and needs.
Can stand without assistance for increasing lengths of time.
Walks alone short distances with irregular unstable steps (between months 13-16).
Climbs stairs by crawling with much more ease.
Increased interest in climbing onto cushions or low tables.
Likes to move around by pushing objects like chairs because they provide an increased sense of stability.
Is able to remove the lid from a container when it is low pressure.
When given a crayon, can make a few marks on a sheet of paper.
Repetition and Trial-and-Error. exhaustively interacts with objects in an effort to learn as much as possible about them.
Enjoys Experiment- Based Play.  “What happens if...?” For example, “What happens if I splash water out of the tub?”.
Greater interest in parts of the body, explores your eyes, ears and mouth with his fingers.
Combines Familiar Actions and  Words.for example, says “ Bye, bye” while waving goodbye.
Understands a broader range of simple instructions, especially if they are accompanied by gestures.
Begins to perceive language as a powerful tool to interact with others.
Can eat with a spoon although he will still spill a lot. It is easier for him to eat thick foods like puree.
Can take off socks, hat and other items that are easily removable.
Learns to Ask for Help. uses limited vocabulary and body language to communicate with others nearby.
Feels as if the world revolves around him/her, sharing is not a strength.
Play is the primary mechanism by which he/she explores and relates to the world around her.
Wants to do everything independently, but realizes that he/she still needs help.
Roll the Ball. is able to roll a ball toward a target with moderate accuracy.
Incorporate other Movements while , Walking.for example, is able to stop and wave goodbye.
Attempts to throw a ball overhead.
Walks in an unstable fashion, frequently falling down and standing back up.
Turns pages in books with thin pages, usually four or five pages at once.
The precision of his/her grasp continues to improve, can grab objects as they move slowly (a ball or a car).
Builds towers of two levels with increasing ease and various types of objects.
Indicates Preferences.when presented with options, demonstrates a preference by pointing to it.
Use of “Tools”. makes use of “tools” to get objects that are otherwise out of direct reach.
Child’s capacity to imitate is increasingly sophisticated  imitates some basic  facial and verbal expressions and some animal and objects sounds.
Recognizes commonly visited locations.
Understands more than 20 words (many understand between 50 and 100).
Increased desire to communicate is evident, although still limited by small vocabulary.
Applies inflections to new words, for example, may raise the tone of voice when asking a question. “more?”.
The majority of the words the child understands are simple and concrete.Can also understand simple actions like, “Let’s dance”.
Frequent use of the word “no” in different contexts.
Able to suck through a straw.
Finishes pulling out his/ her own arms and legs as you help him/ her change out of him/her clothes.
Manifest a wide range of Emotions. for example, love, frustration and jealousy.
Prefers familiar people to which he is frequently exposed  strangers can cause anxiety.
Can entertain himself for a few minutes , as long as you are within sight.
Separation from mom still causes anxiety, this will start decreasing at some point in the next four months.
Seeks to share positive and negative emotions (successes and frustrations) with those which are closest.
Squatting while walking, is able to stop and squat to pick something up, then stand again and continue walking.
Can roll a ball to you and receive it when you roll it back. Can do this several times, consecutively.
If prompted, kicks a ball with low level of precision.
Discovers the ability to carry objects from one place to the other while walking and does this at every opportunity.
Can insert and remove pegs on a toy pegboard.
Spontaneously shows an interest in scribbling.
Using a shape puzzle (square, triangle and circle), manipulates and inserts the circle in its place (other shapes may take more time).
Ability to Anticipate.can begin to anticipate the trajectory of certain objects  knows where a ball will bounce or what direction a toy car will roll.
Initial Notions of the Concept of Quantity. for example, more bread or more water.
Physical development as well as development of other areas allow him/her to imitate social behaviors he/she frequently observes around him/her, such as sweep or clean.
Knows the various steps of each daily routine (bathing, nap time, supper, etc.).
Uses Inexact Word Imitation. as a mechanism for language learning.
Is able to verbally communicate many needs. For example, can ask for water.
Increases the diversity of the intonation and pitch of voice in her babbling.
Can usually make himself/herself understood and gets what he/she wants using facial gestures or body movements.
Can drink out of a cup with no lid with assistance.
Attempts to comb or brush own hair.
Enjoys getting different reactions from those around him/her  enjoys flirting.
More open to sharing with adults than other children.
Remembers social routines and behaviors of those around him/her (saying hello or goodbye).
Throw a Ball. is able to throw a ball with an overhead motion.
Can Change Walking Speed.due to better control over movements.
Climbing off Furniture Alone. for example, can climb off bed or chairs without help.
Is able to lift one foot for a moment if leaning on a piece of furniture.
Is able to walk backwards for a few steps.
Can rip a piece of paper.
Is able to press low pressure lids onto circular containers.
Can guide a toy car or some similar toy back and forth on a path.
Body Parts.when asked, is able to point to a majority of the main parts of the body.
Follows and obeys more complex one-step commands.
Attempts to say the names of close relatives.
Ability to fully pronounce remains limited, resulting in the use of simple names like Dada, Mama, Meema and Popop.
Shows interest in brushing own teeth.
Is able to help pick up toys if you ask.
Initiates some social games with mom or dad, such as passing a ball back and forth.
Displays limited patience (will easily throw a tantrum if not given what he wants).
Will laugh hysterically at things baby finds cheerful or funny.
Climbs stairs holding your hand on one side and the handrail on the other.
While walking, can make a sudden change of direction with more ease.
Increased interest in climbing on progressively taller sofas, chairs and other furniture.
On a ring stacking toy, develops the ability to independently stack rings on the base.
When drawing or painting on a pad or a , large surface, uses entire arm.
Associates familiar people with their respective names.
Can identify major parts of the body on others or in an image of a body.
His repertoire of words continues to  increase (e.g., adds words such as “thank you” or “come”).
Adds the use of the word, “yes” to their vocabulary.
Uses the word “mama” deliberately and proactively to get your attention.
Can use a fork with certain types of food, in a rudimentary fashion.
Can drink from a cup without a lid on their own.
Increasingly helps undress themselves, pulling out their arms as you hold his shirt sleeves or lifting each foot as you pull off the pants.
Norms of Courtesy. begins to understand basic courtesies such as saying “thank you”.
Ability to Walk in different Directions.when necessary, has the ability to walk sideways or backwards.
Climbs up and down stairs holding your hand on one side and the handrail on the other.
Able to walk fast  attempts to run short distances.
Place and Remove Lids. is able to place and remove low-pressure lids from differently shaped receptacles.
Drawing Vertical Lines. attempts to imitate vertical lines (between months 18 and 20).
Towers of Three or Four Blocks. is able to build towers of three or four blocks without assistance.
Spatial Awareness. has a basic understanding of the spatial location of objects and himself (above-below, inside-outside).
Capacity to imitate allows him/her to replicate simple sounds and words (up to two syllables) that he/she hears.
Increased attention span (e.g., able to follow a short story line).
Vocabulary.child has a range of 10-20 words.
Begins to combine words to make phrases such as, “more water.”
Presence of echolalia (repetition of a word or a phrase several times).
Helps wash /hisher own hands.
Enjoys many of his/her favorite games in the company of familiar adults.
Can play by himself/herself for a few minutes without the presence of a parent.
Interested in actions that solicit a response and social interaction (e.g., give and take games).
Struggles to share toys with playmates.
Kick the Ball.can kick a ball with some precision.
Improved coordination and balance allows dancing with some control and falling less frequently when walking.
Able to jump in place with both feet at once.
Is able to throw a ball progressively farther.
Turns pages in books with thin pages, usually two or three pages at once.
Can unwrap some small objects combining various fine motor skills and the ability to tear paper.
Able to string beads with medium sized holes on to a firm cable.
Associates Objects with Activities.  for example, knows that soap and towel are used at bath time.
Once completing an objective (e.g., finishing a basic puzzle), will repeat it  several times, which helps reinforce learning.
Initial Short Phrases. begins to use frequently heard two- or three-word phrases.
Says “yes” and “no” with more purpose.
First phrases include the minimum number of necessary words to make himself understood  (telegraphic language).
Can pull up or pull off pants with elastic bands.
Capable of bringing a spoon to mouth with greater precision.
During the next few months, tantrums can increase, which may sometimes make mealtime, bathtime and other selfCare routines more difficult.
Enjoys Dancing. uses dancing to express happiness and gain social acceptance.
Aware of the presence of other children (still prefers to play alone).
Experiences a broader range of emotions (tantrums and biting can result from these new sensations).
Need for independence will cause him to increasingly try things on his own.
Runs Short Distances.can run short distances with imprecise movements.
Walks forward, backward and sideways , with ease  still struggles to do so on a narrow surface.
Can climb up stairs using support on one hand only, needs support on both sides when climbing down stairs.
Balance while walking continues to improve  can carry larger items without falling.
Drawing Horizontal Lines. attempts to imitate horizontal lines (between months 20 and 22).
Shape Puzzle.can complete a basic shape (square, triangle and circle) puzzle without assistance.
Can open and close zippers.
Play based on Mental Representations.e.g., uses a box to represent a toy car, plays by moving it and making corresponding car sounds.
Starts to understand that the reflection in the mirror is not another baby but rather himself.
Motor skills, ability to imitate and spatial awareness allow her to replicate a variety of body movements during playtime or while dancing.
Decreased reliance on gestures and noises, as his repertoire of words increases.
Combines words and body language to make herself better understood.
Continues to use the same word in various forms. For example, will use the word wa-wa   for water, juice or milk.
Has the ability to use a spoon (to eat solid and semi-liquid food), a fork and drink from a cup with no lid.
Able to help with low complexity household chores (e.g., clean up something that spilled).
Imitates social behaviors of emotion and conduct, such as forms of celebration and dancing.
Incorporates concepts like “mine” and “want” in social interactions motivated by his desire for independence.
Demonstrates pride and pleasure upon completing an objective.
Episodes of frustration start to become more frequent.
Uses available toys to recreate desired adventures (such as playing with a toy plane as it could fly).
Jumping Down.can jump down from a low height.
Kicks a ball, follows it and kicks it again, , consecutively several times.
Changes speed, stops and starts again , with greater ease while walking.
Towers of Four to Six Blocks. is able to build towers of four to six blocks (between months 21 and 24).
Capable of turning round-shaped doorknobs.
Classify into Two Groups. is able to separate objects into two groups based on some characteristic such as size, color or shape.
Concept of Size. has a basic understanding of the concept of size.
Primary Colors. is able to identify some colors, usually the primary colors.
Spatial Awareness. expanded comprehension of the spatial location of objects and himself (in front of or behind  above or below).
Understands the concept of possessive pronouns like “mine”   and   “yours”.
Uses two- and three-word phrases with some (still limited) frequency.
Vocabulary and ability to pronounce some words clearly continues to improve on a daily basis.
Reduced Separation Anxiety.able to endure short spans of separation more easily.
Able to spend more time with other kids, though not proactively interacting with them.
More open to socializing with adults other than immediate family.
Plays at imitating observed adult behaviors, for example, pretending to talk on the phone.
Tests limits and rules set by parents by engaging in defiant behavior.
Wide Range of Motor Movements. navigates obstacles with increasing ease  for example, climbing over, under or walking sideways to overcome them.
Able to climb up and down stairs with only one hand on the handrail (but likes to get support in both hands).
When dancing, can speed up or slow down the body movements, depending on the rhythm of the music.
Runs more frequently, does it in a straight line and have difficulty stopping suddenly.
Drawing Circles.attempts to imitate circular and semi-circular lines (between months 22 and 24).
Able to roll a ball with higher accuracy due to better hand and finger control.
Day and Night.starts to understand the concept of day and night (which provides the foundation to eventually understand the concept of time).
Formation of Numerical Concepts. understands the quantitative difference between one and many.
Identifies basic shapes (e.g., square, circle, etc) when you mention them.
Uses Plurals. in some words or short phrases.
Vocabulary. repertoire includes around , 25-35 words.
Enjoys repeating any word or phrase that she finds interesting or funny.
Babbling starts to diminish.
Participates more actively in bathing routine, helping lather soap, wash down and dry off.
Tries to use napkins by herself.
With a little help, is able to peel some easy-to-peel fruits, such as a banana.
Increased ability to express emotions (including demonstrations of affection and frustration).
Likes to help you with frequently observed activities (e.g., if he sees you sweeping, he wants to do it too).
Likes to share interesting things with you and will take you to them to show them to you.
Kick a Moving Ball.can kick a ball that is moving slowly towards him.
Jump in Place.continues to try, feet barely leave the floor.
Ability to run improves  some children can change direction rather than run only in a straight line.
Folding Paper. if shown how, can fold a sheet of paper in half.
Has the ability to manipulate small objects (e.g., can open a candy wrapper).
Imitates several types of line drawing, but grip on the crayon continues to develop over several months.
Colors. identifies favorite colors in nearby objects.
Recognizes some simple shapes upon holding them, without looking at them (a ball versus a cube).
Memorizes parts of favorite songs.
Starts to identify people outside of the nuclear family by name.
Capacity to imitate words improves greatly  can imitate simple new words immediately after hearing them.
Says her name to refer to herself.
Can eat a variety of foods using utensils without assistance.
Able to undress himself with minimum assistance.
Capable of washing and drying hands with minimal help from you.
Increasingly enjoys the company of other children .
Laughs with people as a mechanism for integration and social acceptance.
Desire for independence continues, but continues to demand your constant attention.
Displays egocentric behaviors centered on his needs and wants.
Climb Stairs Without Help.
Able to climb into a ride-on toy car and push herself along with her feet.
First attempts to jump forward with both  feet (hop forward).
Turning Pages of a Book turns the pages in a book or magazine one by one.
Can copy vertical, horizontal and  circular lines (this skill with gradually improve over several months).
Can complete a simple shape puzzle  even when shapes are mixed up and reversed.
Two-Step Commands.comprehends and executes instructions containing two or in some cases, three steps.
Has a better understanding of the parts of the body, recognizes them and knows their function.
Thinking Before Acting.the child capacity to form symbolic thoughts, allows him to think through and anticipate the consequences of his actions rather than acting impulsively.
Her focus changes from exploring an object itself to understanding its functionality.
Vocabulary.comprehends between 150 and 300 words and can use 50 or more of them (varies widely from child to child).
Phrases of Three or Four Words. Begins to use phrases made of three or four words.
Attempts to combine phrases, pausing , between one phrase and the next.
Word repertoire includes familiar people , objects and several animals.
Able to comb or brush her own hair with minimal help from you.
Tries to use a spoon to consume liquid or foods, although still spills much of it.
Is capable of putting on some types of shoes (without laces and easy to slide into) .
Presence of Parallel Play. plays alongside children but not with them.
Open to sharing space with other children, sometimes even sharing toys.
Means to express emotions extend from actions to facial expressions.
Although her sense of independence  continues to expand, she still has no concept of danger.
